releasenotes/notes/eventlet-monkey-patch.message: Thanks Ken. I'll change this paragraph to try and paraphrase what you've said since there could be multiple ways this could under eventlet + uWSGI/mod_wsgi.

Also might need to change this paragraph based on what Iain explained about how oslo.messaging uses two threads for a message, one for sending and one for replying. The issue might be that in the threads > 1 case, if the thread that sends the message is not the same thread meant to reply, the reply thread might still be asleep/paused/whatever and in that case we never get our reply. When threads=1, we are guaranteed to have the same awake thread send and reply. I don't know how to be 100% sure about this though. I'll try to get kgiusti to review this too.

I know that having multiple threads use the same oslo.messaging transport does allow any thread to re-create the connection.  However oslo.messaging does use threads internally - in addition to the heartbeat thread - for other things.  It may still fail in other ways if run under eventlet with and app that violates eventlets threading guarantees.

there are is at least one other workaround which is to run the nova-api without a wsgi server.

e.g. use the setuptools consol script and run  nova-api with the built in python web server. this will still monkey patch the api but it will not have the reconnection issue as it will not be suspended.

not that the standalone nova-api sript does not have the same  perfomce as when it is executed under a wsgi server like uwsgi however in this configuration you can still deploy it behind a webserver like apache or nginx can be configured as a revers proxy to hanel termination of ssl loadblancing over multiple nova-api instance to achive the desired level of perfomance.
Ack, yes, good reminder. Will add that running the eventlet wsgi server is another good workaround.

Is this the same as or different than running the eventlet wsgi servers that come with nova?

Is disabling the rabbit heartbeat threshold an option?

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/config.html#oslo_messaging_rabbit.heartbeat_timeout_threshold

I was just thinking about this because of this recent bug:

https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1844152

> Is disabling the rabbit heartbeat threshold an option?
 
I don't think so. Not doing heartbeats isn't going to make the connection any less dead - it'll just make it certain that the death won't be noticed until we try to use the connection, where now it may or may not be noticed, depending on threading. There are two aspects to the problem - the noisy messages (disabling heartbeats would solve that, I suppose), and attempting to use a dead connection, which causes messages to get blackholed...

Have a question here.
Are we taking into account the 'subnet_type' here for checking if the floatingIP subnet is using a special service type subnet rather then the external network?
Ok, thanks for the clarification. Just wanted to check if ther service_type is required. Will test it out with the service_type  when this is available.
I have an environment to test this in. I'll try it out, if it warrants a test case we can look at that too.

I don't think the subnet_type matters. What we're looking for is the list of FIP agent gateway ports. The subnet_type only comes into play when choosing an address for the FIP agent gateway port. Here, it has already been addressed and we are simply looking up its IP address and mapping it to a host so that we can join compute ports to their respective FIP gateway ports.

Will the FIP gateway have more than 1 IP address? The only reason I can think of that it would is in a dual-stack environment where it also has an IPv6 address. In that case, L694 and L701 become problematic because it filters out IPv6 host routes which I think we want to advertise.

It's probably a little faster in the worst case to do it the way you suggest. Since speed is of the essence with these lookups, I'm always looking for the most lightweight approach. It's worth a re-spin to pull the subnet ID's first. Thanks for overthinking :)

zuul_registry/storage.py.message: This is UploadRecord.chunks, which serves two additional purposes beyond this method: sum the sizes to calculate the overall upload size, and count the number of chunks in the upload.  We could split those out into other variables, but it would be more verbose, and this seemed the best way to maintain data fidelity (we keep metadata (the size) about each of the chunks throughout the upload; we might add more metadata in the future -- that's why I made it a dict).
We use this to be able to return a size back up to callers. Instead of maintaining a list of chunk sizes can we simply update a value like we di with the upload.count?
Out of curiosity, couldn't we do the move and concatenation together? Then we reduce the number of potential "writes" that have to happen.

This is designed for swift -- we make a SLO out of the chunks ("concatenation"), but when you do that, the original objects are still there.  So first we move the objects out of the upload directory (implemented in swift as an internal copy+delete -- it should be efficient), that way we keep it tidy and can aggressively prune it for aborted uploads.  The additional cost for the filesystem backend is minimal.
This should be now-1 hour: because uploads in progress are unreferenced blobs, so we should give them a grace period.
Possible we may want to consider a pool of threads in the future to limit the number of threads we spawn, but ok for now.

I tried improving the tests but we meet a unittests and tox limitation:

To test this order, I need to have the entry points loaded before resource modules.
This is exactly what happens when using ospurge with this patch.

However, when using unittests, modules loaded by previous tests stay loaded. Even when splitting these tests out in another file.

Therefore it is a limitation of unittests I can't add a test to make sure modules are loaded in a specific order for just one tests because modules are loaded by other tests.

I can check by creating a separate unittests file and launching this file "alone", but when launching all tests I hit a failure.

So to test this I would need a single unittests file launched alone and make sure all other tests are never launched before.

doc/source/deploy_install_guides/r2_rele.message:
I would not group unified, is_secure_registry and ssl_ca_cert together with url, username and password.

url, username and password are attributes of the public registry they are underneath (i.e. k8s.gcr.io or gcr.io etc).
( unified, is-secure-registry and ssl-ca-cert are NOT attributes of a public registry )

unified is under 'docker_registries' structure, but is a special case of k8s.gcr.io or gcr.io or etc ... i.e. it is at the same indent level as k8s.gcr.io or gcr.io or ... ... i.e. it can have url, username and password defined for it.

is_secure_registry is also under 'docker_registries' at the first indent level.

ssl_ca_cert is actually NOT under 'docker_registries' at all.
It is a top level parameter ... since it could be used independent of 'docker_registries'.   It's just that using a secure private registry is the most common example of why you'd need to use this, so thought I'd talk about it in this section.

paunch/utils/common.py.message: I don't think this is right either, because what if it's [0, 1, 7, 8]

cpu_affinity can be a list of independent CPUS "0,12" as well as a range of cpus, or a combination of both, such as "0-3,12-15"

Yet, for a range, psutil.Process().cpu_affinity() returns a complete list of allowed cpus:
For instance:

# taskset -c 0-3,12-15 python
>>> import psutil
>>> psutil.Process().cpu_affinity()
[0, 1, 2, 3, 12, 13, 14, 15]

So, we can return the cpu_affinity "as-is", after a string transformation
cpu_affinity = ','.join([str(c) for c in psutil.Process().cpu_affinity()])
which will return '0,1,2,3,12,13,14,15'

I would recommend to propagate the error in case it fails, Reader uses random generator from OS [1], that can result in error [2], which may potentially lead to having an insecure (too short) passphrase.

[1] https://golang.org/pkg/crypto/rand/#pkg-variables
[2] http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/getrandom.2.html#top_of_page
Unfortunately, since this function completes an interface, the error can't be propagated. I've included a fatal log for it, with the hopes that this will basically never happen.

pkg/secret/passphrases.go.message: defaultLength or we can define a new const minLength

Sorry for a naive question, but I'm wondering if it was possibly to use the implementation from Uint64 and do:

    randIdx = randUint64 % len(pool)

This is mostly academic, but modulo is inherently flawed for generating uniform random numbers. See this SO question for details on why https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13104478/uniformity-of-random-numbers-taken-modulo-n

Although requesting from a user to have a password with all characters including is considered to be a good practice to ensure he/she generates a better password, I'm wondering if it is necessary when the password is by definition random (i.e. machine generated).

I hadn't really considered this point. This implementation was lifted from the current Pegleg implementation [0]. In the end, I don't think it matters whether the password contains a character from each set or not, but I see no reason not to. If we can come up with a reason this is detrimental, I'll remove it.

[0] https://opendev.org/airship/pegleg/src/branch/master/pegleg/engine/util/cryptostring.py#L67
Would strings.Builder be a cleaner fit for this?  I think it uses a byte buffer under the hood, but is geared specifically for strings.

I found what appeared to be contention between the 4byte-asn tests and the basic tests when they run in the same job. After VERY careful analysis of the logs, it appeared to me that the tests were either interleaved or executing at the same time. It looks to me like that causes some starvation due to the fact that there is only 1 agent, and multiple BGP speakers in existence. Only one of them will get scheduled, and subsequent checks for peering status on the unscheduled BGP speaker's peers will obviously time out. If I'm right, separating these into different jobs will get us by for now. I think the tests will need more work to be able run them in a single job.
I didn't know that was possible, I'm not very familiar with zuul. We may be able to run *everything* from one job, which would be more efficient.

I think the overhead of stacking 4 or 5 different environments dwarfs the amount of time spent running all of these tests serially in a single job. From what I can tell, in each job an overwhelming amount of time is spent simply stacking the environment. If we only incur that overhead once, it may be more efficient and might actually finish faster. There actually aren't that many tests here.
That sounds good, I see on current Zuul run 3-5 tests per job, so one serialized single job should not take much more time than the current ones

1) you are calling the helm init command.  This will work in 1.15 but fail in 1.16 (today).  That doesn't mean that a version of tiller won't be released sometime in the next few months that does work with 1.16
2) You are passing the output from p1 into p2.  p1 does not generate a yaml file through the --output command, it is doing the init.  The "sed" will not find the apiVersion in that output, but also won't fail.

p1 = helm init (some args) --output yaml  (this is creating a yaml structure)
p2 = sed  (this alters the yaml
p3 = kubectl apply (this applies the yaml

Ah right, this was changed recently, I will address this in the next patch, I see in the the centos, this is done in the %post section, is there a reason it's done there vs here in the %install for centos?

These should be done after the RPM is installed not when it is built, hence they are in %post section.

The reason they are copied to the /etc/ansible so that default inventory and Ansible config customizations are applied regardless of what directory the bootstrap playbook is executed (from).
I see. I'll do the same for CentOS in my next opportunity.
Yes, this address scripts with shebang but without the execute bit set.

I was not clear in my previous reply to your question. The reason the file copies are placed in the %post section of the centos spec is because they replace the files installed by another package (Ansible package). Place them in the %install section will lead to file conflict.

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/resto.message: I might have missed this in the original review. Why is this task required?

When ansible_remote_tmp is set to the default which is under /tmp, we don't need to specifically delete it. But when it is set to somewhere else, e.g. /home/sysadmin/ansible-restore, we need to delete it when restore platform is done. 

Regarding setting ansible_remote_tmp to a non default value, I have following in restore instruction:

"The <ansible_remote_tmp> should be set to a new directory (no need to create it ahead of time) under /home/sysadmin on controller-0 via the “-e” option on the command line."
[We can replace "/home/sysadmin" with something more generic.]

The workaround proposed by Ovidiu might not work, because per the standard Ansible variable precedence rules, setting ansible_remote_tmp via -e option on the command line has the highest priority, which means we cannot set it to a different value by set_fact in the playbook. Correct me if I am wrong. :)

I believe it is used to clean the staging area used by the copy module.

From playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/backup-restore/transfer-file/tasks/main.yml:

    # Because Ansible copy module uses ansible_remote_tmp directory as
    # a staging area to transfer file, the default ansible_remote_tmp
    # which is set in /tmp (1GB) may be too small for backup tarball,
    # we require user to set ansible_remote_tmp to a new directory in
    # /home/sysadmin via -e option on the command line. For example:
    # -e "ansible_remote_tmp=/home/sysadmin/ansible-restore"

I moved it at the end, this cleanup is needed even if procedure fails.

This looks dangerous to me, it should remove only the files created during this procedure, not the entire folder, user may set ansible_remote_tmp to /home/sysadmin and this will delete it.

A workaround, in case ansible does not clean after itself, is to create a subfolder in a user specified location, one that we own, set ansible_remote_tmp to it, then remove this subfolder at the end of the procedure.

This doesn't fit here. Please move to B&R section and provide a better name and description to prevent misuse. By default (normal bootstrap), the disks should be wiped. So something a long the line...

# The following flag should be overwritten in host override
# file as needed when the node is bootstrapped to restore a
# system only. By default, Ceph OSDs are wiped as part of
# the bootstrap.
wipe_ceph_osds: true

For restore, we want the default behavior to be not-to-wipe-the-disk. 

For normal bootstrap, we don't even check this boolean and the osds will be wiped.

So if we change the boolean name to wipe_ceph_osds, by default it should be set to false.

wipe_ceph_osds: false

We have this condition for the wipe-disk task:

- name: wipe osd disks
  ......
  when mode == "bootstrap" or (mode == "restore" and
                               wipe_ceph_osds)
After Wei's directory restructure commits, this should be removed. The restore_ceph_data flag is set in backup_restore/default.yml.

ok, I will have to get rid of one of them. Since by default we expect users to keep their clusters I think wipe_ceph_osds looks better than restore_ceph_data. At least users know that their OSDs will be wiped only if set to true. This also aligns with the rest of the abstractions (i.e. in sysinv). restore_ceph_data implies that either we or them have to do something to restore their ceph data.
One of the options is used during stx-application restore, the other one during platform restore. I'll update restore_ceph_data to better match the context.

The restore_platform playbook imports bootstrap playbook and runs it in “restore” mode instead of the default “bootstrap” mode. 

We can set the condition of "Wipe ceph osds" task like this:

- name: Wipe ceph osds
    script: cleaning_partitions.sh 
    become: yes
    become_user: root
    when: (mode == “bootstrap”) or
             ( mode == “restore” and recover_ceph_data == false)

So for a full restore, we will play the restore_platform playbook with recover_ceph_data set to false:

> ansible-playbook ../restore_platform.yml -e "recover_ceph_data=false, backup_filename=......"

For a partial restore, we will play the restore_platform playbook like this:

> ansible-playbook ../restore_platform.yml -e "backup_filename=......"

For normal bootstrap, we don't need to set either recover_ceph_data or backup_filename.
So you want to avoid the case where, in a normal bootstrap, the user sets recover_ceph_data=true?

In a normal bootstrap osds should always be wiped no matter user sets recover_ceph_data or not. And to me user shouldn't be aware of "recover_ceph_data" when doing normal bootstrap. When doing restore, by default, osds shouldn't be wiped. User needs to specify "recover_ceph_data=false" to wipe osds.

This task does not belong to prepare-env role. It should be done after all configuration inputs have been validated. If it must be done before the bootstrap manifest is applied then place it in validate-config role right before "bootstrap_config ini file generation" block.

Please also verify that the task is idempotent and the underlying script is reentrant (ctrl-c to simulate network disconnect in the middle of the wipe and rerun the playbook).

doc/source/user/concepts.rst.message:
I don't think this is the best place for this documentation.  This file is all about introducing basic concepts of Zuul.  It's for people who have never used Zuul before, and we need to tell them what gating is, and that Zuul uses something called Ansible to run jobs.  The section added is more configuration reference than introductory material.

My preference would actually be to omit this in Zuul docs and only document it in Nodepool.  Once all supported versions use "auto", that will make a lot of sense.  But now we are in a weird situation where there is still some logic dealing with this in Zuul, so it would be weird not to describe that in Zuul's docs somewhere.  So if we want to keep this in Zuul's docs too, then I'd suggest putting it after this section:

https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul/admin/components.html#executor
